node.title: A Frenzy of Book Banning
node.description: The right-wing war on school libraries.
node.content: ["Virginia\u2019s Spotsylvania County School Board this week voted unanimously to have books with \u201csexually explicit\u201d material removed from school library shelves. For two members of the school board, this didn\u2019t go far enough; they wanted to see the books incinerated. \u201cI\u2019m sure we\u2019ve got hundreds of people out there that would like to see those books before we burn them,\u201d said one of the members, Kirk Twigg. \u201cJust so we can identify, within our community, that we are eradicating this bad stuff.\u201d", "This was just one example of an aggressive new censoriousness tearing through America, as the campaign against critical race theory expands into a broader push to purge school libraries of books that affront conservative sensibilities regarding race and gender. Deborah Caldwell-Stone, director of the American Library Association\u2019s Office for Intellectual Freedom, told me that during her 20 years with the organization, \u201cthere\u2019s always been a steady hum of censorship, and the reasons have shifted over time. But I\u2019ve never seen the number of challenges we\u2019ve seen this year.\u201d", "In Texas and South Carolina, Republican governors have called for action on \u201cobscene\u201d content in school libraries. Public schools in Virginia Beach have pulled books including Toni Morrison\u2019s \u201cThe Bluest Eye\u201d out of their libraries pending the results of a challenge by conservative school board members. Schools in North Kansas City, Mo., have done the same with books including the acclaimed memoir \u201cFun Home\u201d by Alison Bechdel and \u201cAll Boys Aren\u2019t Blue,\u201d a book of essays about growing up gay and Black by George M. Johnson. In Flagler County, Fla., a member of the school board filed a criminal report over the presence of \u201cAll Boys Aren\u2019t Blue\u201d in her district\u2019s school libraries, claiming it violated state obscenity laws.", "With the rush to ban critical race theory, conservatives already gave up posturing as defenders of free speech. Still, this sudden mania for book banning is striking. It\u2019s part of a broader attack on public schools, one that draws on anger over critical race theory, mask mandates and sometimes even QAnon-inflected fears about pedophile conspiracies.", "\u201cWhat I\u2019ve started to call more and more frequently the war on books, it\u2019s getting wrapped up in all kinds of anti-school activities,\u201d said Richard Price, an associate professor of political science at Weber State University who runs the blog Adventures in Censorship.", "It\u2019s important to acknowledge that some amount of parental shock at envelope-pushing young adult literature is understandable. As in the days when the Christian right tried to rid libraries of Judy Blume, books whose frankness about taboo subjects intrigue teenagers can horrify their elders.", "One frequently targeted book is the 2019 graphic memoir \u201cGender Queer.\u201d Its author, Maia Kobabe, wrote an illustrated column about the uproar over the book in The Washington Post, with a thought bubble saying, \u201cWhy are they mad about the book? Because I said nonbinary and trans people exist?\u201d Perhaps, but I\u2019d guess that some parents are also mad about the images of fellatio. It\u2019s easy to imagine \u201cGender Queer\u201d being a great comfort to a confused and lonely 16-year-old, but it\u2019s just as easy to see why conservatives would find it outrageous.", "The transgressive nature of some recent young adult literature, however, isn\u2019t enough to explain the current nationwide campaign to cleanse libraries of works seen as unwholesome. For one thing, at most schools, parents can already block their own kids\u2019 access to books they object to. And many of the works the right is now up in arms about have been out for years. The Texas lawmaker Matt Krause recently sent school districts a list of around 850 books that he wants information on. Among the titles to be investigated are William Styron\u2019s \u201cThe Confessions of Nat Turner\u201d and Jeffrey Eugenides\u2019s \u201cMiddlesex.\u201d", "Ashley Hope P\u00e9rez\u2019s award-winning \u201cOut of Darkness,\u201d about a romance between a Mexican American girl and a Black boy set against Texas\u2019s 1937 New London school explosion, came out in 2015. Until this year P\u00e9rez, a former high school English teacher who is now an assistant professor at Ohio State University, hadn\u2019t heard of any controversy around it. But now her book is regularly denounced by school culture warriors. The group No Left Turn in Education, which was founded last year to fight critical race theory in schools, has it on a list of books that are \u201cindoctrinating kids to a dangerous ideology.\u201d", "In September, a Texas anti-mask activist named Kara Bell read a passage from \u201cOut of Darkness\u201d at a school board meeting. The scene she chose was one in which a gang of racist white students sexually demean the Mexican heroine.", "Bell quoted the characters making a slang reference to anal sex, words that left her appalled. \u201cI do not want my children to learn about anal sex in middle school!\u201d she cried. \u201cI\u2019ve never had anal sex! I don\u2019t want to have anal sex! I don\u2019t want my kids having anal sex!\u201d", "Video of Bell went viral, and P\u00e9rez was deluged with furious and sometimes violent messages, often accusing her of promoting pedophilia. Jonathan Friedman, director of free expression and education at PEN America, told me he was accused of being a pedophile simply for defending the presence of \u201cOut of Darkness\u201d in school libraries. \u201cThere\u2019s definitely some kind of QAnon element taking place here,\u201d he said. After all, the paranoid belief that liberalism is a front for pedophile cabals is a staple of the QAnon conspiracy theory.", "This spreading moral panic demonstrates, yet again, why the left needs the First Amendment, even if the veneration of free speech has fallen out fashion among some progressives. Absent a societal commitment to free expression, the question of who can speak becomes purely a question of power, and in much of this country, power belongs to the right.", "\u201cWhat we\u2019re seeing is really this idea that marginalized communities, marginalized groups, don\u2019t have a place in public school libraries, or public libraries, and that libraries should be institutions that only serve the needs of a certain group of people in the community,\u201d said Caldwell-Stone. The fight about who controls school libraries is a microcosm of the fight about who controls America, and the right is on the offense."]
